p.seg: 3. Doubting the Ancients
The tasks of the historians in antiquity
were divided in two:
one was to record the words (that were spoken)
the other was to record the actions.
However, the learning of the scholars of antiquity
was focused on the words.
For example: of the rules of Yu and Xia,
the decrees of the Shang and Zhou,
the words of Zhong Hui and Zhou Ren
and the discourses of Shi Yi and Zang Wen
All the speeches of wandering orators, responses of foreign envoys, advice or written suggestions to a ruler,
there is none that is not quoted
or returned to as a model.
For the (records of) actions, things did not go that way.
Shao Hao named his officials after birds,
Yao Tang tamed dragons in order to be appointed to an official position,
When the Xia went into temporary decline,
Hou Xi and Han Zhao were among the villains (responsable).
When the state of Qi was first established,
(making for) unheard-of (events) and remarkable actions.
(the clans of) Pugu and Boling were among its rulers.
All of these founded states or supported their dynasty,
The scholars of later generations, however,
only rarely transmitted any explanations about them.
whereas the documents recording words were viewed as important.
This goes to show that the works of history that recorded the actions did not circulate (widely)
may perhaps have some coarse knowledge about small aspects of them.
Only a gentleman of vast learning
As for the tradition of Zuo (Qiuming; i.e., the "Chunqiu Zuozhuan"),
although the exegesis is basically conform to the classic (the "Chunqiu"),
he (also) talks about various other things.
Therefore, the Confucians of the Han dynasty
resented it intensely.
Thus, the (other) two traditions (i.e., "Gongyang zhuan" und "Guliang zhuan") circulated widely
and were the only ones to gain renown in the course of time.
Among the writings of Confucius and his disciples,
the "Lunyu" only transmits words and remarks,
while the "Kongzi jiayu" also reports actions and deeds.
simply calling them "Lunyu".
Since antiquity, however, scholars and followers have handed them (these texts) down,
This demonstrates
that it is clearly the result of the ancient's constantly making light of (records of) actions and taking words seriously.
Thus, starting from Yao of Tang and
ending with Mu of Qin,
there are only a hundred chapters of records about them in the "Shangshu".
And that which the "Shangshu" transmits
focuses on words.
When it comes to rise and fall (of states etc.) and to actions and events,
it (the "Shangshu") does not even record one.
I could still say a lot about the omissions (of the "Shangshu")!
It is stated in the "Lunyu":
"The gentleman works to perfect what is splendid in others,
and he does not work to perfect what is ugly in others."
It is also said:
"Matters that are completed one does not explain,
what is past one does not censure."
matters that have gone their proper course one does not remonstrate on,
It is also said:
"The common people may be made to follow one,
they cannot be made to understand one."
Therefore, the people of later generations today learn about the words,
(but) the actions of the emperors and kings of Tang, Yu and the states that came thereafter
have not yet become known.
Those were the words of Confucius when he established his teachings.
With regard to works of historiography,
his opinion was the same.
Thus he called good what was good on the basis of its goodness,
and, even if it had bad aspects,
did not criticise it any more;
and he called bad what was bad on the basis of its badness,
and, even if it had good aspects,
should not be praised any more.
This is why Mengzi states:
(just as) Jie and Zhou were not completely bad."
"Yao and Shun were not completely good,
Wei Wendi said:
"I know about the precedents of Yao and Shun."
Han Jingdi said:
"It is not because of ignorance that the scholars in their discussions don't talk about
how Tang and Wu received the Heavenly Mandate."
All these also show that the worthies of former times also looked closely (at their sources)
and already had a preliminary understanding (of it).
Although their mouths could not express it,
they knew in their heart which (parts) were not right.
Of these cases, there turned out to be a lot.
However, they were (also) constrained by rites and law
and these limitations were applied to teaching and instruction.
Then, as regards the historiographical work of Lu, the "Chunqiu":
For the sake of (protecting the image of) the worthies on the outside
and for the sake of the inside (stability) of the state itself,
the precedents were twisted and roughly woven,
and all the actions were concealed or avoided as taboo.
This then (is in accordance with) the authoritative words of the Duke of Zhou.
This being so, what need is there for the "Chunqiu",
that is not (already) covered by the Six Classics?
They are all like this.
Thus, when we examine how Confucius revised the "Shangshu",
(we see that) Jie of the Xia ceded his throne to Tang (of the Shang)
and that the King of Wu beheaded Zhou (of the Shang).
These precedents are very clear,
but nevertheless they were omitted (during the redaction by Confucius).
(Note:
These events are from the "Documents of Zhou".
The "Documents of the Zou" are the remainder of those of the "Shangshu" that Confucius eliminated (when he was supposedly compiling the "Shangshu").)
When we examine how Confucius gave the Chunqiu its definite form,
(we know that) Yin and Min did not die of natural causes
and that Wu and Shi did not live to old age,
however (the Chunqiu), with a boastful brush and splendid words,
states that "in Lu, there is no usurpation or killing of rulers."
When we examine how Confucius eliminated (parts of) the "Shijing",
(we see that) all the (parts of the songs from) "Guo Feng"
contain resentful blame and reprimands
but that there are no (songs) about Lu.
When we examine Confucius' "Lunyu",
(we see that) a ruler (i.e., Duke of Zhao) takes a bride from Wu
who has the same surname (as he does),
and that when the Sheriff (of Chen) asked Confucius (if the Duke of Zhao understood about ritual propriety),
he responded that he "understood ritual propriety".
This proves that the wise man (Confucius) pretended to be wise and bragged about it in front of stupid people,
and that he often loved and hated on the basis of his own whims.
Additionally, the precedents transmitted by the old text (i.e., the "Shangshu")
are written in a brief and concise way;
those who put (the precedents) forward are hard to find out
and there is no information to fill the gaps.
As a consequence, none of the scholars of later times got to the bottom of its sources,
and, stupidly, they did not look into it at all,
as if they were deaf and dumb.
Today, (those who) doubt the precedents (of the "Shangshu") are therefore scolded
and (everyone) relies on the work.
There are ten instances (of doubt about the events in the Shangshu) in total,
which I arranged in the following.
About the excellent Fang Xun (i.e., Yao) it is said in the "Yu shu" (Documents of Yu):
"(Yao) was able to make bright his lofty virtue,"
and Lu Jia also said in his "Xin yu":
"Of the people of Yao and Shun
every household deserved to be enfeoffed."
It would appear that he wrote these remarkable words on the basis of the "Yao dian."
The "Chunqiu (Zuo) Zhuan" says that,
in the clans of Gao Yang and Gao Xin, there were eight (lines of) talented descendants each.
They were called "The Great" and "The Triumphant".
(The descendants of) these sixteen clan lineages
lived up to that excellence generation after generation,
maintaining their reputation.
When it came to (the time of) Yao (however),
he could not appoint them to a high office.
The clans of the emperors Hong, Shao Hao, and Zhuan Xu all had (a line of) untalented descendants,
who were respectively called "Chaots"
and "Blockheads."
"Monsters,"
(The members of) these three lineages
lived up to their violent nature throughout the generations
and increased their bad reputation.
When it came to (the time of) Yao,
he could not dismiss them.
The clan of Jinxu also had an untalented descendant,
whom everyone called "Glutton."
He and the three (other) clan members
were jointly called "The four miscreants"
but Yao still could not dismiss them.
This shows that, during the time of Yao,
ordinary men and gentlemen
there was no distinction between good and bad,
and the competent and the stupid were all lumped together.
rubbed shoulders and were considered as equal,
It is also stated in the "Lunyu"
that Shun raised Gao Yao in office
and that the wicked were (thus) held at bay.
Therefore, at the time when Gao Yao had not yet been raised in office,
the wicked (must have) abounded,
which proves even more (clearly) that during the time of Yao, commoners were in positions of authority.
How then did it come to be said (in the "Shangshu") that Yao "was able to make bright his lofty virtue"
and (in the "Xinyu") that (of the people of Yao and Shun,) every household deserved to be enfeoffed?
This is my first doubt.
It is also stated in the preface of the "Yaodian" (of the "Shangshu"):
"(When Yao) wished to abdicate,
he yielded his throne to Shun of Yu."
Confucius' comment states:
"Yao knew that his son, Dan Zhu, was unworthy (of inheriting his throne),
therefore he wanted to abdicate (in favour of Shun)."
However, the fragments from the tomb of Ji also state
that Shun sent Yao to Pingyang.
And the documents say that
there was a certain town
which was called "Imprisoning Yao."
Those who are aware of this and rely on this diverging explanation
very much doubt (the "Shangshu"'s assertion) that he (Yao) abdicated (in favour of Shun).
This being so, these two documents (the fragment from the tomb of Ji and the unknown source cited above)
but there still remains something that I don't yet understand.
already suffice as proof,
What is it?
According to the "Shanhaijing" (The Classic of the mountains and seas),
Fang Xun's (i.e. Yao's) son became the emperor Dan Zhu
and his name was listed among those of the emperors.
Does that not mean that, even if Shun had done away with Yao,
Yao's son was nonetheless installed (on the throne),
and was thereupon again usurped (by Shun)?
In the recent past,
there were some who publicly denigrated outstanding persons,
They either deposed the father and established the son as ruler,
or they dethroned the older brother and raised the younger one (to rule).
In the beginning, they make a show of promoting and supporting (the new ruler),
but in the end, they will wrest (his throne) from him as well.
In all the dynasties of the past,
there have often been (situations like this).
If we compare the past and the present,
(we find that) thousands have transmitted the same standard of behaviour.
Thus, as for Yao's handing the throne over to Shun,
the events are hard to comprehend;
it is said that he (Yao) yielded the state (to Shun),
if one listens to and follows false reports.
This is my second doubt.
It is also stated in the "Shundian" in the "Yu shu":
"It was only after 50 years (as emperor)
that (Shun) went on an imperial tour and died."
The comment states:
"He died in the wilderness of Cangwu,
therefore he was buried there."
When Cangwu
was (part of the territory of) Chu, the river was called Miluo,
and during the Han dynasty, the cities there were called Ling and Gui.
The entire region (was populated by) the hundred tribes of Yue,
and the mountains there form five ridges.
The people there wear tattoos
and the air is muggy and miasmatic.
But even if you send the heir of an estate of a hundred gold pieces there,
he will still respect the proper principles and tread on their path;
how much more will a ruler over ten thousand chariots
be able to undertake the inspection (of this place) so as to rejoice in his state?
Then Shun must have carried out an exhaustive inspection in an excellent manner,
his appearance showing his hardships,
and set aside his high rank,
just as one discards a heavy load.
How can it be then, that in the year he died,
he set foot in (such) a barren place at all?
Moreover, his two concubines did not accompany him,
thus leaving him companionless,
with no support for ten thousand miles.
He died alone.
like this?
How could they have let their ruler go far away
When we consider one by one how the rulers of others were deposed and exiled since ancient times,
(we see that), for example, Jie of Xia was banished to Nanchao,
Jia of Zhao was deposed to exile in Fangling,
the King of Zhou was sent to Zhi,
and the Emperor of Chu was removed to Chen.
In speaking of their misery,
there are still (many) others (whose end was) just as bad as theirs.
Was it perhaps the will of Yu that he died like this in a remote place?
This is my third doubt.
A document from the tomb of Ji states:
"Shun sent Yao to Pingyang
and (Bo) Yi was executed by Qi."
It also states:
"Tai Jia killed Yi Yin,
and Wen Ding killed Jili."
The reports of all these events
differ from the official classics.
If these documents had only been recently unearthed,
many of the people of this age would not believe them.
As for Shun's sending away Yao,
there is no precedent which contradicts this,
which is enough to prove the truth of it,
as has already been made clear in the foreword to this chapter.
For (the statements) that (Bo) Yi and Yi Yin were executed, however,
there is equally no evidence in the official writings.
If this were to be discussed,
(it would become clear that,) Qi's having (Bo) Yi executed, for example,
could still be investigated.
Why?
Shun deposed Yao and established Dan Zhu as ruler,
Yu banished Shun and had Shang Jun enthroned.
(Bo) Yi took over control of the state
and became just as powerful as Shun and Yu.
He wanted to stay in conformity with the precedents,
taking on the good fortune bestowed by Heaven.
His actions were not successful, however,
and he brought disaster upon himself.
If we now examine usurpations of ancient and modern times,
(we see that) only (in the case of Duke) Huan (of Qi the usurpation) was not achieved,
(because) Feng (Qian killed him and thus) restituted the straight path.
Could Qi's having (Bo) Yi executed
have been for the same reasons as Emperor An of Jin's ordering Huan Xuan to be killed?
When Yu replaced Shun,
and brought all his actions to success,
only to see (his plan of installing Bo) Yi (as emperor) upturned
was that the same as when Huan Xuan tried to emulate the Cao and the Sima
but only achieved the downfall of the Emperor An of Jin?
because of the Qi's fault,
This is my fourth doubt.
The preface to "The vow of Tang" (in the "Shangshu") says:
"Tang (of the Shang) atacked Jie (of the Xia) (...)
and they fought at Mingtiao."
It is also said:
"Tang banished Jie to Nanchao
but felt ashamed of his conduct."
But the chapter "Blessings of the Yin" of the "Zhoushu"
says in praise that Jie ceded the throne to Tang and so on.
This (account), then, diverges from (the one in) the Shangshu.
could it be then that Tang did not defeat Jie,
(did not) strive to control the people of Xia,
If things (really) were the way they are explained in the "Zhoushu",
(that he did not) force Jie to abdicate
and give the throne to himself?
Why wouldn't he want to to keep up with Yao and Shun
and follow their lofty reputation?
According to "Mozi",
Tang was going to yield the realm to Wu Guang,
but let others say by way of explanation that
he wanted to give him a bad reputation.
Wu Guang thereupon threw himself into a clear cold spring and died.
Tang then acceded to the throne without being doubted.
Like with Tang's pretended abdication,
there are many more records of false acts like these throughout history.
When one studies that which is said in the "Mozi",
(it seems that) it coincides beautifully with (what is stated in) the "Zhoushu".
Now
the "Zhoushu"
was originally derived from the "Shangshu."
Confucius (in compiling the"Shangshu") eliminated the unnecessary ornamentations
and cut (i.e., edited) it into a refined text.
He discarded the vulgar parts,
(and made Tang appear) morally straight by saying that he "felt ashamed of his conduct."
Could it not be that he wanted to cover up Tang's wrong-doing
and to increase Jie's bad (reputation)?
This is my fifth doubt.
In the writings of the Five Classics,
thousands of events are transmitted in such a way that they seem admirable,
but when one tries to comprehend them from beginning to end,
their principles appear extremely contradictory.
How so?
They say that during the prime of (the ruler) Zhou,
It is also stated that when the Shang was ruined,
Zhòu had a hundred million subjects
and that when he fell there was a terrible bloodbath.
but (they also say that) Zhòu was a solitary man.
he was said to hold two of the three parts (that constitute all under Heaven)
This then is not unfounded,
and the [different] representations are incongruous.
And as for the King of Wu's
recounting of Zhòu's mistakes and failures in the "Great Oath" (in the "Shangshu),
it is just like Lü Xiang's breaking off Jin's relations with Qin in our times
or Chen Lin's declaration (of war) to Wei on behalf of Yuan Shou:
If one wants to place the blame on them,
can it be done without (inventing) a pretext?
But all the masters of later times
continued the tradition of this false discourse
and vied with one another
in laying out Zhòu's faults,
doubly more so than in the Five Classics.
This is why Zigong said that
the evilness of Jie and Zhòu was not that bad,
and that (this is why) the gentleman hates dwelling among the lowly people.
Ban Gu also asks
how he (Zhòu) could have relied on a woman to deal with the dynasty.
Liu Xiang, too, says that
among their contemporaries there were some who assassinated their fathers and harmed their rulers,
and that Jie and Zhòu did not reach this (level of wickedness).
However, the wickedness of the world
is always supposed to have started with Jie and Zhòu.
Doesn't all this talk about the crimes of Xin (i.e., Jie) and Gui (i.e., Zhòu) since ancient times
constitute severe slander?
This is my sixth doubt.
In the preface of "Prince Wei's Mandate" it is said:
"(King Cheng of Zhou) killed Wu Geng (because he rebelled against him)."
Lu Fu (i.e., Wu Geng) was the son of Zhòu of the Shang.
When the altars of earth and grain (i.e. the nation) were toppled
the dynasty (of the Shang) collapsed,
(Wu Geng's) father's (i.e., Zhòu's) head was publicly displayed,
and his mother's body was torn apart.
For a long time he was only talked about with hate and shame,
he might as well have been dead.
Supposing that he submitted to Zhou
thus saving himself and protecting his wife and children:
how could he even live like this?
he would have had to be on his guard at all times,
As a human being,
how could he maintain the proper appearance?
After a while he would have conspired (to overthrow the state) together with Shu Xian of Guan and Shu Du of Cai
and the three guards (i.e., the rebel leaders) died defending their cause.
Although he had hung on to his resentment towards those close to the ruler,
his earnestness as a minister was obvious.
If one were to judge him by the teachings of the Confucians,
(one could only say that) he was free of guilt in life as well as in death.
Those who argue that he was not successful in achieving (his goals)
take him to be a worthless troublemaker.
This is my seventh doubt.
Supposing (things really) were that way,
then the ruler would have been like Shao Kang of the Xia
and the subject like Wu Zixu.
And if Wu Geng had got rid of his enemy and had taken his revenge,
his army defeated and he himself destroyed,
wouldn't he surely have been treated like a slave, followed by the shame of his past,
and been classified as a member of the rebels?
The "Lunyu" says that
the Zhou had great charismatic power (?),
and that they held two thirds of All under Heaven
and still served the Shang.
However, the preface in the "Shangshu" states:
"The Prince of the West (i.e., the later King Wen of the Zhou) had killed (the prince of) Li,"
and "the Shang started to loathe the Zhou."
Now when the Ji clan (i.e., the Zhou) was appointed a feudal lordship
and immediately launched a military campaign (against Zhòu),
They collaborated with and (at the same time) hated the royal house
without the least bit of shame or respect.
This, then, is what the "Chunqiu" talks about when it says that the Jingman defeated the Ji (clan),
and what the "Lunyu" means by "the Ji clan was about to attack Zhuanyu."
Yet another text says that
when there were overwhelming flocks of bright red birds,
King Wen received the mandate to call himself king and so forth.
Just as there cannot be two suns in the sky,
The lords of Yin were still persisting (to rule)
there cannot be two (rightful) rulers on earth.
and the (same) ruler still sat on the throne;
so this (situation) would have been like the one in the "Chunqiu" when Chu, Wu and Yue usurped the title and acted against the ruler.
In that case, then, when (King Wen) defeated (the prince of) Li and removed (the Marquis of) Wu,
declaring himself to be equal to a king,
this (behaviour) could not possibly be conform to the way of a servant (to a ruler).
This would be just as when, in more recent times, Sima Zhao of the Wei dynasty had a great minister murdered,
banished Cao Mao,
in addition received the nine bestowments
and rode on a chariot with six horses.
When it came to his death,
Xun Xu still called him a servant (to a ruler) until the end (of his life).
As it turns out, the Ji's (i.e., the Zhou's) servitude to the Yin
can be fittingly compared to Sima Zhao's servitude to the Wei;
so if one speaks about the greatness of the virtue of the Zhou,
would that not be a lie?
This is my eighth doubt.
It is said in the "Lunyu":
"Taibo (...) must definitely deserve to be said to have reached the point of moral authority.
Three times he declined to take over all under Heaven,
but the people in no way found anything to praise him for."
But the transmission in the "Lüshi Chunqiu" goes that
King Tai (i.e., Gugong Danfu, Tai Bo's father) concentrated his care on his grandson (i.e., Jili's son Chang)
and wanted to instal the father of the latter on the throne.
(But) Tai Bo was the son of (King Tai's) first wife
and this position obstructed the ascent of the worthy (i.e., Jili) to the throne.
If he had stubbornly looked on,
and harboured doubts that could not be dispersed,
in the worst case he might have been executed (by his father) like Ji of Wei,
all fall under the category of words.
and in the best case hemight have been chased away like Jian of Chu.
So even if he did not want to renounce his right to the throne,
would not his father installed him (Jili on the throne) anyway?
Furthermore, upon King Tai's death,
Taibo came to make a formal announcement,
in order to put off leaving the throne to his brother.
put off
but Jili took advantage of the investigation of [his father's] death
and [thus] had an excuse to leave.

because the external circumstances put an end to his doubts
Also according to the Chunqiu Zuozhuan,
when Shiwei of Jin became aware that [the crown prince] Shensheng would be killed, he said [to him]:
Do it like Taibo of Wu [and flee],
at least you will have a good reputation.
This shows that for Taibo and Shensheng,
the events were the same.
so their outcome was not the same, either.
But because the points of departure of the two were different,
So Confucius in talking about Taibo
had to gloss over the fact that his virtue came from distress
and turned disaster into good fortune,
this is what actually happened.
Equally, when he says that [Taibo] "must definitely deserve tobe said to have reached the point of moral authority",
is there, then, no mistake in praising him like this?
This is my ninth doubt.
In the chapter "Golden coffer" of the Shangshu it is said that
[the rulers of] Guan and Cai [i.e., the brothers of King Wu of Zhou] spread talk saying that
"The prince [i.e., their brother Dan, Duke of Zhou] will do no good to the infant."
The Zuozhuan says:
"When the Duke of Zhou killed the rulers of Guan and Cai,
how could this be because he did not love them?
The [real] reason was the [preservation of the] dynasty."
It says in the chapter "Lord Shi" of the Shangshu,
"With the Duke of Shao serving as guardian
and the Duke of Zhou acting as tutor,
they assisted King Cheng
as his left and right hand.
The Duke of Shao did not [try to] persuade [King Cheng]."
[but that] he held the power of a mighty leader;
because he thus attracted public slander and criticism.
the traces [of the records] lead one to doubt that it was so,
This would mean that Dan [the Duke of Zhou] in his behavior did not follow the ritual proper to a minister,
Although Shi's [the Duke of Shao's] virtue was inferior to that of a sage,
and he shouldered the task of creating credibility [for the Duke of Zhou],
on close examination of these events, it looks
as if he [still] harbored anger and deep dissatisfaction.
how can one not feel suspicious?
and hears such diverging opinions from the side,
And especially when one considers [the fate of] his two brothers,
who were from the center of the place [the capital, where the events transpired]
but were assigned to dwell in the periqhery,
Because [of the records saying that] they took up arms to betray [the dynasty],
these events have misled me.
But because the Duke of Zhou was insincere,
he in addition had them immediately publicly executed.
[In comparison] with the pardon of Prince Huainan
and the lenience displayed towards Fuling of the Han dynasty,
how much further could these lie apart!
This goes to show that the Duke of Zhou was weak in righteousness towards his friends.
But the way the Shangshu transmits this account
is full of praise for him,
how can this be?
This is my tenth doubt.
For the most part, the writers who lived during the period of the Shangshu before the Chunqiu period
recorded the events in this way [as shown above].
If one picks up their true Classics and elegant words today,
it is hard to understand their principles [in writing].
The different teachings of the various masters
can perhaps be relied on [in the search for] what is right;
one can check them against one another
in order to study them in detail and get to the bottom of each.
If one diverges from this pattern,
there is no doubt [about its fault].
As for the writings of early antiquity
not only do they, in their manifold essence, not conform to the same categories,
but they even differ [in their claims] and contradict each other.
and the works of history of late antiquity,
Why is this?
In the works of history redacted in late antiquity
words were only recorded after having been investigated in detail,
and the events were deliberately chosen after the proper assessment.
If the scholars were to examine the governing of a state,
they would weigh good and bad against each other;
or if they were to investigate the talent of a ruler,
[they would conclude that] competence and foolishness both amounted to about half and half.
In early antiquity, however, it was not so.
In the things [the scholars of that time] recorded in writing,
they would briefly refer to rough outlines,
striving to preserve [due] praise and to respect taboos,
look for the beginning and end [of an event],
concealing and omitting a lot.
and that the rulers Yao, Shun, Yu and Tang
Supposing that one were to say that
the emperors of Han, Wei, Jin and Song
lived in early antiquity,
were born in the middle period:
they would command the historiographer officials to turn things upside down in writing about them,
in every event of the time they compiled
and when they assessed achievements;
[the consequences] would be immeasurable.
Just like Cartwright Pian who called [the Classics] dregs and chaffs [of the ancients],
Confucius would have [been able to] record the doubts he wanted to transmit.
The Mengzi says:
"If one believed everything in the Shangshu,
it would be better if it did not exist.”
I examined 23 writing slips from the Shangshu chapter "Completion of the war."
I infer [from my findings]
that the writings of early antiquity
include very grave mistakes.
Perhaps if one compared them to the falseness of Wang Shen
and to the deceitfulness of Shen Yue,
they would turn out to be similar.
Taibo already had been physically hurt,
